description: From an Old French diminutive of baïf (“open-mouthed”), from baer (“to gape”), from Medieval Latin *badāre, present active infinitive of bado (“I gape, yawn, am open”), probably of imitative origin.  Related to Italian badare.

adjectives.description: bevel (comparative more bevel, superlative most bevel)

entries.meaning: Having the slant of a bevel; slanting.
An edge that is canted, one that is not a 90-degree angle; a chamfer.
examples: to give a bevel to the edge of a table or a stone slab

entries.meaning: An instrument consisting of two rules or arms, jointed together at one end, and opening to any angle, for adjusting the surfaces of work to the same or a given inclination; a bevel square.
(gambling) A die used for cheating, having some sides slightly rounded instead of flat.
examples: The different types of dice made for cheating (flat passers, bevels, cut edges, loaded dice,  […]

verbs.description: bevel (third-person singular simple present bevels, present participle (UK) bevelling or (US) beveling, simple past and past participle (UK) bevelled or (US) beveled)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To give a canted edge to a surface; to chamfer.
